deliberation: Looked for metaphors, similes, and metonymies. The key imagery is leaders as hunting equipment (snare/net) causing others to stumble at Mizpah and Tabor. Also evaluated whether “house of Israel/house of the king” are metonymic (they are conventional but still figurative).

instances.english_text: for you have been a snare at Mizpah
target: the priests and ruling house at Mizpah
ground: causing unsuspecting ones to be caught and harmed
dangerous, deceptive entrapment
moral/spiritual misguidance
instances.explanation: The priests and leaders are portrayed as a hunting snare at the cult center of Mizpah, emphasizing that instead of guiding people they trap and ruin them spiritually.

instances.english_text: and a net spread out over Tabor
target: the same priests/royal house influencing Tabor
ground: wide-ranging, concealed danger leading to capture
broad influence that ensnares many
systemic spiritual entrapment
instances.explanation: Leadership is also depicted as a net draped over Mount Tabor, suggesting pervasive and inescapable corruption that ensnares those who come there.

instances.english_text: House of Israel ... and O royal house
target: the people of Israel and the royal family
ground: the household stands for those who live in and belong to it
corporate identity represented by a single house
collective representation via dwelling imagery
posture: direct address in covenant lawsuit style
solemn summoning of all responsible parties
instances.explanation: “House of Israel” and “royal house” use the image of a physical house to stand for the people and dynasty, a standard metonymy where the dwelling denotes its occupants.

deliberation: The Hebrew is difficult, but in the given reading trappers dig deep pits. Considered whether this referred literally to physical traps or figuratively to plots and deep corruption. The context of deceptive leadership suggests figurative plotting imagery.

instances.english_text: for when trappers dug deep pitfalls
ground: secretive, deliberate efforts to ensnare others
depth suggesting intensity and hiddenness
premeditated schemes to cause others to fall
instances.explanation: The verse depicts the schemers as trappers digging deep pits, a metaphor for their covert, carefully prepared plans to lead others into ruin.

deliberation: Searched for figurative uses: the key terms are sexual infidelity (זנה) and ritual impurity (טמא) used of Ephraim/Israel’s relationship to God. In Hosea this sexual language is a controlling metaphor for idolatry, and purity language for moral defilement.

instances.english_text: Behold, you have fornicated, O Ephraim
ground: breaking exclusive loyalty, seeking other partners
betrayal of a covenant relationship
shameful and intimate unfaithfulness
instances.explanation: Ephraim’s religious and political disloyalties are portrayed as sexual fornication against God, casting idolatry as marital betrayal.

instances.english_text: Israel has defiled himself
target: their sin in turning from YHWH
ground: becoming unfit for God’s presence
stain and pollution that separate from the holy
contaminated status needing cleansing
posture: warning about exclusion from God’s presence
instances.explanation: Israel’s sin is cast in the imagery of ritual defilement, implying that their behavior has made them unclean and unfit to approach the holy God.

deliberation: Looked for agency attributed to abstractions and internal drives. Two candidates: their deeds not allowing them to return (personification) and “spirit of whoredom” within them (metaphoric internal force for idolatrous desire).

instances.english_text: Their deeds do not let them turn back to their God
target: the sinners themselves in their habits
the moral-spiritual state of the people
vehicle: deeds as agents that "do not allow"
controlling authorities that forbid an action
ground: their past actions now exert controlling power
sin has become a master that prevents repentance
self-imposed bondage through behavior
posture: warning about consequences of habitual evil
instances.explanation: Their own deeds are personified as gatekeepers who refuse permission for them to return, emphasizing how their behavior now dominates and prevents repentance.

instances.english_text: Because a spirit of whoredom is within them
target: the psychological/spiritual root of their sin
vehicle: an inner force characterized by sexual infidelity
ground: an inner driving force that compels behavior
pervasive, controlling tendency toward betrayal
domineering influence leading to idolatry
posture: prophetic unveiling of hidden motive power
instances.explanation: An internalized, idolatrous impulse is depicted as a ‘spirit of whoredom’ inside them, a metaphor for their deep, driving tendency to covenant unfaithfulness.

deliberation: Key possibilities: (1) “pride of Israel” doing something before his face, likely personified as a witness (cf. Hos 7:10); (2) “will stumble/fall in their guilt” as a standard metaphor for moral/spiritual failure and collapse.

instances.english_text: Israel’s pride shall answer/testify before his very eyes
target: the internal disposition of the nation
vehicle: pride as someone who speaks or testifies
a witness giving an answer in court
ground: their arrogance itself serves as evidence against them
inner attitude becomes vocal testimony
their sin is self-condemning
posture: prophetic irony that their own pride convicts them
instances.explanation: Pride is personified as a witness answering before them, conveying that their own arrogance rises up as evidence of guilt in God’s courtroom.

instances.hebrew_text: וְיִשְׂרָאֵל וְאֶפְרַיִם יִכָּשְׁלוּ בַּעֲוֹנָם כָּשַׁל גַּם־יְהוּדָה עִמָּם
instances.english_text: Israel and Ephraim shall stumble in their iniquity; Judah also has stumbled with them
vehicle: loss of footing on a path
ground: sin causes loss of stability and downfall
moral error likened to tripping and falling
progress interrupted by collapse
instances.explanation: Their moral failure and coming judgment are depicted as stumbling on a path, a metaphor for how sin makes them lose stability and fall into ruin.

deliberation: Examined “going with flocks and herds to seek YHWH but not find Him” and “He has withdrawn from them.” The cultic seeking is literal action, but the language of seeking/finding and withdrawal uses spatial search/removal as a metaphor for relational access and divine favor.

instances.hebrew_text: יֵלְכוּ לְבַקֵּשׁ אֶת־יְהוָה וְלֹא יִמְצָאוּ חָלַץ מֵהֶם
instances.english_text: They will go to seek the LORD, but they will not find Him; He has withdrawn from them
target: Israel’s attempt to regain God’s favor
the reality of God’s relational distance/judgment
vehicle: seeking and not finding a person who has gone away
someone withdrawing himself from another’s sphere
ground: restored relationship pictured as locating someone present
judgment as the beloved party pulling away
loss of access and presence signifying rejection
posture: critiquing empty ritual without true repentance
instances.explanation: The language of seeking and not finding, and of God withdrawing, uses spatial imagery as an idiom for relational distance and rejection: God is metaphorically ‘gone’ from them.

deliberation: Considered three elements: (1) “they have dealt treacherously with YHWH” in a book saturated with marital imagery; (2) “they have begotten alien children” likely continuing marriage/offspring metaphor for a foreign, illegitimate generation; (3) “the new moon will devour them” uses time/occasion as a devouring agent, clear personification/metaphor.

instances.english_text: They have broken faith with the LORD
vehicle: unfaithfulness of a spouse or ally
ground: violation of pledged loyalty
secretly turning against one’s partner
covenant as a bond that can be betrayed
posture: framing sin as betrayal of trust
instances.explanation: Their idolatry and political disloyalty are cast in terms of betrayal toward YHWH, drawing on marital and treaty imagery for covenant unfaithfulness.

instances.english_text: Because they have begotten alien children
target: the next generation shaped by idolatry
vehicle: offspring that do not belong to the true husband/father
ground: producing a generation who does not truly belong to YHWH
their ‘children’ are foreign in allegiance and character
fruit of their unfaithfulness is an alien progeny
posture: warning about long-term effects of idolatry
instances.explanation: The community shaped by their idolatry is portrayed as ‘alien children,’ offspring who do not truly belong to YHWH, extending the marital/parental metaphor.

instances.english_text: Now the new moon shall devour their portion
vehicle: a calendrical occasion as a ravenous eater
ground: an appointed time consuming what they have
judgment at a festal time reversed into destruction
celebration day turned into devouring loss
posture: depicting judgment as inescapable and timed
instances.explanation: The ‘new moon’—normally a time of festivity—is personified as a devourer that consumes their portion, a metaphor for a coming appointed time of loss and judgment.

deliberation: Most of the verse is straightforward battle alarm language using literal shofar/trumpets. The notable figurative element is the renaming of Bethel as Beth-aven (“house of evil/vanity”), a polemical metonym and wordplay, not just a geographic label.

instances.english_text: Give the alarm in Beth-aven
target: the cult center at Bethel and its worship
the idolatrous shrine and community using it
vehicle: polemical renaming of a sacred place
ground: the sanctuary is dominated by iniquity, not God
its true character is vanity/evil instead of ‘God’s house’
place-name stands for its corrupt cultic practice
instances.explanation: Calling Bethel “Beth-aven” (house of wickedness/vanity) is a polemical renaming where the place-name stands metonymically for its corrupt cult and character.

deliberation: Reviewed “Ephraim shall be a desolation/shammah on a day of rebuke; among the tribes of Israel I have made known what is sure.” These phrases can describe literal devastation and a literal day of judgment. There is no comparitive image or personification beyond normal prophetic diction.
Identified two explicit כ- comparatives: (1) princes of Judah likened to boundary-movers, a moral simile; (2) wrath poured out like water, a vivid simile for overwhelming judgment.

instances.english_text: The officers of Judah have acted like shifters of field boundaries
ground: deliberate, unlawful encroachment on what belongs to others
greedy violation of established limits
abuse of power to gain advantage
posture: aligning them with classic covenant curses
instances.explanation: Judah’s leaders are likened to those who illegally move boundary stones, highlighting their corrupt encroachment on what is not theirs.

instances.english_text: On them I will pour out My wrath like water
target: God’s exercise of judgment on Judah’s leaders
vehicle: a deluge or torrent covering someone
ground: wrath coming in a sudden, overwhelming flood
inescapable engulfing of the guilty
abundance and intensity of judgment
instances.explanation: God’s wrath is compared to water poured out, emphasizing the overwhelming and inescapable nature of the coming judgment.

deliberation: Assessed whether oppression/crushing are literal or figurative; they plausibly describe real political oppression. The distinctly figurative phrase is “he walked after command/futility,” using walking after as a path metaphor for following empty human precepts/idols.

instances.english_text: Because he has willingly gone after futility/command
target: their obedience to human or idolatrous decrees
their orientation of life and worship
vehicle: walking after something on a path
following behind a leader on a journey
ground: ordering one’s life by following a guide
pursuing and adhering to something
choosing a path of allegiance
posture: showing their active, willing pursuit of emptiness
depicting idolatry as a chosen path
instances.explanation: Ephraim is said to ‘walk after’ a mere command/futility, an idiomatic path metaphor for deliberately ordering life according to empty human or idolatrous precepts.

deliberation: The verse has two parallel כ- similes: God like a moth to Ephraim and like decay to Judah. Both express slow, consuming judgment through imagery of destructive agents.

instances.english_text: For it is I who am like rot/moth to Ephraim
target: God’s mode of judgment on Ephraim
the national strength and prosperity of Ephraim
vehicle: a moth that eats away fabric
a small insect that silently destroys
ground: quiet, often unnoticed consumption from within
eventual ruin of what once seemed intact
fragility under persistent nibbling damage
posture: depicting judgment as subtle but inexorable
warning that ruin is already at work
instances.explanation: God likens Himself to a moth to Ephraim, portraying His judgment as a slow, inward consumption that quietly ruins their strength.

instances.english_text: and like decay to the House of Judah
target: the stability and institutions of Judah
ground: internal breakdown over time
corruption that eats away from inside
eventual collapse due to unseen rot
posture: emphasizing inner corruption rather than external blow
instances.explanation: God compares Himself to decay for Judah, signaling that His judgment will work like rot, corroding their strength and institutions from within.

deliberation: Noted a coherent illness-healing metaphor: Ephraim sees his ‘sickness’ and Judah his ‘wound’ and seeks healing from Assyria. This is not literal physical disease, but a metaphor for political/spiritual crisis and the vain search for help.

instances.hebrew_text: וַיַּרְא אֶפְרַיִם אֶת־חׇלְיוֹ וִיהוּדָה אֶת־מְזֹרוֹ ... וְהוּא לֹא יוּכַל לִרְפֹּא לָכֶם וְלֹא־יִגְהֶה מִכֶּם מָזוֹר
instances.english_text: Yet when Ephraim became aware of his sickness, Judah of his sores ... He will never be able to cure you, will not heal you of your sores
target: the political and spiritual crisis of Israel/Judah
their need for deliverance and restoration
vehicle: bodily sickness and sores needing healing
a patient seeking a physician’s cure
ground: serious but diagnosable condition
dependence on a healer for recovery
wrongly seeking help from an inadequate physician (Assyria)
posture: critique of misplaced trust in foreign powers
portraying their plight as needing divine, not political, remedy
instances.explanation: National and spiritual trouble is depicted as sickness and sores, and Assyria as an incompetent physician who cannot heal, forming a medical metaphor for their misplaced reliance.

deliberation: Two parallel כ- clauses describe God as a lion and young lion to Ephraim/Judah, elaborated by tearing and carrying off prey. This is a sustained predatory-animal simile for God’s violent, inescapable judgment.

instances.english_text: For I will be like a lion to Ephraim
target: the encounter between God and Ephraim
ground: sudden, overpowering violence
tearing and killing with no resistance
prey’s helplessness before the predator
posture: intense threat emphasizing fear and inevitability
countering any view of God as harmless
instances.explanation: God likens Himself to a lion against Ephraim, depicting His judgment as a sudden, overpowering predatory attack that the nation cannot withstand.

instances.hebrew_text: וְכַכְּפִיר לְבֵית יְהוּדָה אֲנִי אֲנִי אֶטְרֹף וְאֵלֵךְ אֶשָּׂא וְאֵין מַצִּיל
instances.english_text: and like a young lion to the House of Judah; I, I will attack and stride away, carrying the prey that no one can rescue
vehicle: a young lion seizing and carrying prey
predator that tears and walks off with its kill
ground: strength and agility to seize and carry prey away
no rescuer can snatch prey from such a lion
complete control of the victim’s fate
posture: declaring absence of any human savior
instances.explanation: God compares Himself to a young lion toward Judah, elaborating that He will tear, carry off, and that none can rescue—an extended simile of predatory capture for unavoidable exile/judgment.

deliberation: Considered two main anthropomorphic/idiomatic expressions: (1) God ‘going and returning to His place’ as spatial withdrawal for relational distance; (2) Israel’s ‘seeking My face’ as idiom for seeking God’s presence/favor, not literally locating a physical face.

instances.english_text: I will go, I will return to My place
target: God’s withdrawal of active presence and help
the change in His relational stance toward Israel
vehicle: a person physically leaving and going home
ground: distancing oneself from another
no longer being available or present in the same way
withdrawing engagement and accessibility
posture: presenting judgment as God’s deliberate withdrawal
explaining Israel’s experience of divine absence
inviting reflection on cause of that withdrawal
instances.explanation: God’s decision to ‘return to My place’ uses human spatial movement as a metaphor for relational and protective withdrawal from His people.

instances.english_text: Till they seek My face; in their distress they will seek Me
target: desire for restored relationship and favor
their response of repentance in distress
vehicle: anxiously searching for a person’s presence
ground: seeking access and favor from a superior
desiring face-to-face presence and approval
earnest pursuit expressed as search
posture: portraying repentance as active pursuit of God
showing distress as catalyst for seeking
hopeful note that judgment will lead to renewed search
instances.explanation: ‘Seeking My face’ is an idiomatic metaphor for earnestly seeking God’s presence and favor, not literally looking for a physical face, indicating relational restoration as their goal.
